intro: Melampodium hidalgoa, commonly known as Hidalgo's goldenweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and showy yellow-orange blooms. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky soils. It has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, tubular flowers that attract pollinators like bees and butterflies. Melampodium hidalgoa is often used in native plant gardens due to its ornamental value and drought tolerance.
